A/P:  Mr. [**Known lastname 512**] is a 73 yo male with CAD with preserved EF, type 2
DM, HTN, HL, h/o CVA, s/p AVR on coumadin, admitted with septic shock
likely secondary to pneumonia and RLE cellulits.
1.  Septic shock.  Patient has leukocytosis and fever, making septic
shock most likely.  Most likely source pneumonia given significant
consolidations on chest CT, however per family patient was without
significant pulmonary complains.  Alternative source would be RLE
cellulitis.  Will evaluate for other sources with blood, urine,  stool
cultures, but no other localizing symptoms from family.  Currently on
Levophed and Vasopressin.  Vasopressin was added overnight so that
levophed dose could be minized.    Cortisol normal.
- continue levophed / vasopressin to maintain SBP
- currently volume replete, but bolus prn for low urine output
- continue Vanco/ Zosyn to cover severe community acquired pneumonia
2.  Cellulitis.  Patient has history of LLE cellulitis and now presents
with increased redness, warmth, and pain in RLE.  Patient has history
of MRSA cellulitis.  Also with elevated WBC and fever.  Cellulitis is
covered with vancomycin.  Patient is currently anticoagulated and had
negative CTA, so will not evaluate for DVT at present as it will not
3.  Respiratory failure.  Patient intubated for hypoxia and respiratory
failure.  Initially on 100% FIO2 with PEEP 15 and o2 sats in low 90s.
Likely secondary to significant bilateral pneumonia, thoguh CXR and CTA
initially read as pulmonary edema.  Oxygen requirements have been
reduced overnight.  BNP significantly elevated as well, so may have a
- wean FIO2 to 40%  and then PEEP to 5 if possible
- vanco/zosyn for severe community acquired pneumonia
4.   Sedation.  Patient developed hypotension following fentanyl bolus
that responded to fluid bolus and up-titration of levophed &
vasopressin.  Increased fentanyl however improved tachycardia.  Given
s recent onset of visual hallucinations and history of
agitation with opioids and benzos, anticipate that sedation will be
5.  Tachycardia.  Patient had tachycardia overnight.  Tachycardia did
not respond to fluid boluses for Tylenol for fever, but improved with
increased sedation (though this caused patient to be hypotensive).
6.  Anticoagulation.  Anticoaguled for A. fib and aortic valve.  Will
hold coumadin for now and monitor INR.  No need to bridge with heparin.
7.  ARF.  Baseline Cr of 1.3.  Now 1.7.  Elevated Cr may reflect
worsening baseline in patient with HTN and DM, with prerenal vs. atn
component.  Urine lytes suggest patient is pre-renal.  S/p 6L IVF.
Continues to have low urine output.
Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate) in discussion with family, they
would like aggressive management short of CPR for now and will
re-evaluate if patient fails to improve.
